case_vignette: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician with a 2-month history of difficulty concentrating at work. He is worried he may lose his job due to poor performance. He feels constantly tired but attributes his fatigue to waking up early most mornings and being unable to fall back asleep. His wife has noticed that he has been speaking more slowly than usual and his appetite has decreased. He used to enjoy dance classes with her but has not been as interested in this recently. He is a veteran who returned from a deployment to Afghanistan 2 years ago.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

trial_2.summarized_mcq: Major depressive disorder. The patient's symptoms of trouble focusing, feeling constantly tired, speaking more slowly, and not feeling hungry, along with the reported concerns about work performance and mood, are consistent with major depressive disorder. Acute stress disorder and post traumatic stress disorder may also present with some of these symptoms, but they typically include additional features such as anxiety, fear, or re-experiencing traumatic events. Persistent depressive disorder, also known as dysthymia, is a chronic form of depression characterized by a persistent low mood, but it may not present with all the symptoms described in this case.
